posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked:
Is the REV Time if Flight sensor legal for FRC? If so does anyone have any experience with it or know how to wire it to a RIO?

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Average Rating: 4

Price: USD 29

Thanks!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Class 1 laser, COTS under $600. It’s legal, just please don’t aim near eyes even though it’s Class 1.

Someone else can cover wiring it in.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Good Luck with I2C on the roboRIO although our testing on our roboRIOs had one device on the MXP working okay but more than one failed randomly. Of course, the onboard is officially essentially not usable. Some very knowledgeable people show how to connect to another computer to avoid even the MXP.

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked:
Just realized the REV sensor is out of stock. I also have my eye on this one. Not that much more expensive + it has a CAN interface with a vendor library.

Laser distance measurement sensor with integrated CAN interface.  Based on the ST VL53L1X Time of Flight (ToF) sensor, the SEN-36005 can measure distance up to four meters at up to 50Hz.  Device is preconfigured for a 1 Mbit CAN bus (controller area...

link_counts.title: Playing With Fusion - CAN Bus Time of Flight Range, Distance, and Proximity Smart Sensor

posts.name: hpeyerl
posts.cooked: We’re using the PWF one and it’s awesome.  Works surprisingly well though I have no experience with other ToF sensors.   We haven’t tried it at long range though.  Mostly just sub 2m.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
We have been trying to get the PWF tof sensor to work with 2023 wpi lib and rio image.  We tried both in labview and Java.  We haven’t gotten it to work and seems like the 2023 update have broken something in the PWF lib.

We did get it to work with 2022 wpi lib and rio image.

Just wondering if you got it up and running on 2023 yet?

posts.name: hpeyerl
posts.cooked:
As far as I’m aware, our team is running the 2023 wpi/rio code.   It looks like there was an update to the pwf library on Jan 17.  Are you running PlayingWithFusionLibrary2023.01.17.zip that one?

I’m not the programming mentor so I’ve only been watching from the sidelines.   I can confirm details on Monday afternoon.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
Are you programming in Java?

I will double check to see what version of the PWF lib they are using.

Thanks

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
sthump:

Just wondering if you got it up and running on 2023 yet?

Yes, redux Ri3D had multiple up running on 2023 wpilib/RIO images.

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked:
May want to use their vendordep.

https://www.playingwithfusion.com/frc/playingwithfusion2023.json

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked: Yea my planned use case is like < 2 inches.

posts.name: Ice1605
posts.cooked: Just to add another datapoint, we got our PWF ToFs working yesterday with our Java codebase using their 2023 library, the latest Rio image, and the latest WPILib version.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Jus:

< 2 inches

Pushing the extremes doesn’t always turn out well:

3.3 Minimum ranging distance The minimum ranging distance is 4 cm. Under this minimum distance, the sensor will detect a target, but the measurement will not be accurate.

There may be better proximity switches than the CAN ToF from Playing With Fusion, if that’s the only application.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: One more piece of info about the Rev sensor. If I remember correctly, its address is hardcoded and is the same as the color sensor, so without a coprocessor, you may have difficulty running both at the same time.

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked:
Ok, interesting I did not catch that. It may still work in the use case because ill be checking if something is either fairly far away or very close.

There may be better proximity switches

Do you happen to have any suggestions? Thanks!

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: We’ve used Sharp devices from Pololu. They are various ranges. The proximity switches are the Sharp distance sensors with a threshold for closer/farther on/off.  Sorry I have to run and can’t look up the exact ones we used now. They are digital on/off. IIRC! sorry.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
we have these. There are many others, also.

This small digital distance sensor detects objects between 0.5 cm and 5 cm (0.2″ and 2″) away. With its quick response time, small size, low current draw, and short minimum sensing distance, this sensor is a good choice for non-contact,...
